Graphical abstract Small metallic clusters -mediated gas phase catalysis studies give lights to understand simple and complex catalytic processes, and help in the discovery and explanation of non-traditional “molecular-scale” catalytic systems. In this framework and in the context of clean energy sources based on hydrogen, a comparative study about ammonia borane (AB = NH3BH3) dehydrogenation tendencies, using Pt4, Au4, and Pt2Au2 clusters as catalysts, is made. Molecular details on thermal, kinetic (mechanistic) and reactivity factors are revealed. Our results indicate that all the metal tetramers studied here tends to dehydrogenate the ammonia borane molecule, being the processes exothermic, exergonic and fast. Among the studied catalysts, Pt2Au2 shows the best results, because is capable of easily detach several hydrogen atoms, with high probability of taking them out simultaneously, both from B and N, which helps in avoiding the breakage of B–N bond of AB, what is known to produce the poisoning of the catalyst by ammonia generation. Abbreviations AB ammonia borane Keywords Ammonia borane Dehydrogenation Gold-platinum cluster catalyst Theoretical study Hydrogen 1 Introduction Small metallic clusters -mediated gas phase catalysis studies not only help to clarify metals-catalyzed chemical processes that occur in this aggregation state, but also give lights to understand homogeneous and heterogeneous more complex catalytic processes, and help in the discovery or in the explanation of non-traditional and unsuspected catalytic systems. With respect to its utility in the understanding of more complex homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic processes, it is well known that gas phase experimental and theoretical studies have the advantage of helping to reveal thermodynamic and kinetic details in an isolated and fairly detailed way, not possible to obtain in situ in systems as complex as solutions, biochemical systems, surfaces, supported clusters, etc [1–8]. For example, reaction mechanisms can be systematically inquired by correlating few experimental variables, while, at the same time, due to the simplicity of the systems, they can be modeled with quantum-mechanical methods at good levels of theory [2,4,6,9–11]. With respect to non-traditional and unsuspected catalytic systems, due to the advances in techniques of synthesis and analysis of structures at molecular scales, and the increasing interest in subnanometric systems, there has been a series of prospective studies aimed at stabilizing or generating in situ small metallic clusters in order to exploit their extraordinary catalytic properties. For example, there are several studies about techniques of encapsulation of the small metallic clusters in cavities of some types of zeolites [12–15], or even in nanotubes [16]. In some cases, by manipulating structural and compositional parameters it is possible to manage the selectivity and catalytic performance of these small clusters against various types of molecules and reactions. Specifically interesting here is the report of catalytic properties of cavity-encapsulated planar Au4 clusters (Au4@ZIF-8 and Au4@ZIF-90) [15] with similar geometries to the ones described in this study. Another example is the encapsulation and stabilization of small metallic clusters into metal-organic frameworks, MOF, which are very versatile structures [17,18]. For example, it has been possible to distribute Pt2° clusters within MOF with catalytic activity useful for low temperature industrial reactions [18]. A final relevant example is the in situ generation of small gold clusters of 3 to 10 atoms in solution, which, because of their small size, are capable of producing huge reaction turnover numbers at room temperature for several organic reactions [19]. Again here, predictive and explicative experimental and/or theoretical gas phase fundamental studies about small metal clusters catalytic activity are very important. In particular, theoretical studies based on quantum mechanical calculations, apart from providing details not possible to reach with experiments, have strong stimulating power for new experimental prospections. On the other hand, the availability of high hydrogen concentrations in a safe, controllable and economical way is nowadays increasingly desirable for the wide use that hydrogen has in the chemical industry and for its hopeful possibilities as a non-polluting fuel. Although hydrogen has been applied to transport in devices such as rockets, some airplanes, buses, and automobiles [20,21], this type of application is still restricted. This is because hydrogen has a series of technical and economic drawbacks about its storage, transport and release [20–22]. It is estimated that the chemical storage of hydrogen has several important advantages respect to its storage in compressed or condensed form [21,23]. Among the possible chemical storage media, hydrides are identified, and in the last decade, ammonia borane (AB = NH3BH3) stands out, with 19.6% of its weight in hydrogen. Due this characteristic, and for its stability and relative ease availability of its hydrogen, AB is postulated as an efficient and safe storage media [24]. Among the different ways to get hydrogen from AB is the thermolysis, by means of which it is possible to release a hydrogen molecule at about 120 °C [24,25]. Extracting the remaining hydrogen equivalents is an energetically more demanding process and, therefore, not appropriate for several uses. A very good alternative is the catalysis using transition metal nanoparticles. In this case at low temperatures or at room temperature promising results are obtained using platinum [26,27], cobalt [28,29], nickel [28,30], rhodium [27], ruthenium [27,31], and copper [28] nanoparticles. Platinum nanoparticles are among those that have shown the best results towards the dehydrogenation of AB [26,27]. By contrast, gold -which in general, in the form of nanoparticles, is one of the noble metals with the best results in catalytic processes- has shown a moderate activity for AB dehydrogenation [26]. However, as has been the case for other relatively inactive metal nanoparticles, the increase in irregularities, such as low coordinated atoms, structural edges and vertices, increases also nanoparticles catalytic activity towards AB dehydrogenation [23,29]. In fact, as was mentioned above, small gold clusters of 3–10 atoms -i.e. with high degree of “structural reactivity”- formed in solution give huge reaction turnover numbers [19]. Another advantage of gold nanoparticles is that precisely by controlling its structural and dimensional characteristics, it is also possible to guarantee the availability of activated hydrogen on its surface: the H-Au binding force is not so high as to prevent its easy diffusion on the gold surface, and, hence, its chemical handiness [32–37]. For several reasons, noble metal clusters of 4 atoms have been used as appropriate and convenient models in homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [32–34,38]. In this study we will restrict ourselves to the use of gold, platinum, and gold-platinum tetramers as catalytic systems for the study of some comparative characteristics for the dehydrogenation of molecular AB. Our purpose is to obtain basic scientific information about dehydrogenation tendencies in gaseous phase; we do not intend to solve, through this study, the technological problem of AB dehydrogenation, and even less in a particular medium, as it is, for example a solid support, or some solvent. One important issue to be solved previously is to find the gas-phase most stable structures for the species that will be faced in the catalysis. In the case of isolated AB, which has been very studied [24,39–42], the matter is simple, and the most probable conformation is the staggered one [24,42]. For isolated noble metal tetramers there are several possible configurations and some electronic states for each stoichiometry. For them experimental and theoretical studies have been reported [43,44]. Due to the current difficulties of isolating, manipulating and analyzing gaseous clusters in neutral charge state, the determination of their structure is a big challenge. Despite this, using the far-IR multiple photon dissociation in a molecular beam technique in combination with theoretical calculations, Fielicke et al. [43,45] found that in the case of Au4, a rhomboidal-like and a “Y”-like almost isoenergetic configurations are the most probable geometries. In our research group we have previously studied gold, platinum, and gold-platinum tetramers with high theory levels and relativistic effects [44], and we have confirmed the Fielicke et. al. findings. We also have predicted that among possible combinations of Pt and Au, Pt3Au, Pt2Au2 or PtAu3, the Pt2Au2 stoichiometry is the one with the best tendency towards reactivity, which also showed distorted rhomboidal-like and “Y”-like configurations as the lowest energy structures [44]. By including spin-orbit coupling, with two-component relativistic ZORA Hamiltonian at PW91/TZ2P theory level, the Pt4 lowest energy configuration corresponds to rhomboidal-like [44] one. The “Y”-like geometry is at 0.217 eV above the rhomboidal-like. For completeness, and to appreciate some reactivity aspects of unstable structures, the “Y”-like configuration for Pt will be also considered in the present study. For the Au4 and Au2Pt2 cases, by including spin-orbit coupling at the same theory level, their lowest energy structures tend to be rhomboidal-like and distorted “Y”-like [44]. At the approximation level of this study we will not include spin-orbit coupling; this is so because the amount of calculations and combinations of configurations required in this study is enormous, which makes the use of calculations with spin-orbit coupling impractical. However, the most relevant contributing spin multiplicities for the AB/catalyst adducts will be considered as guide for all computations. Preliminary calculations showed us that singlet and triplet spin states are enough to account for the lowest energy structures of AB/catalyst adducts, even for the AB/Pt4 case (it is known that isolated Pt4 has lowest energy structures with spin multiplicity greater than 3). In summary, the goal of this work is to make a comparative gas-phase study for Au4, Pt4, and Au2Pt2 clusters with respect to their greater or lesser tendency to dehydrogenate an AB molecule. For this, after exhaustive exploration of quantum mechanical potential energy surfaces of the (AB)/(lowest energy tetramers) pairs -in where activated adducts and products can be recognized- energy profiles with relevant structural, thermal and kinetic information for adducts transformation are constructed. Finally, to rationalize the results, a reactivity analysis is presented for the relevant molecular species. 2 Theoretical and computational procedures 2.1 Potential energy surfaces (PESs) of AB/Au4, AB/Pt4 and AB/Au2Pt2 systems 2.1.1 Isolated systems (AB, Au4, Pt4, and Au2Pt2) The starting structures of isolated systems, the AB molecule and the Au4, Pt4 and Au2Pt2 clusters, were obtained by conventional gradient-based geometry optimization methods using the Gaussian 09 package [46]. The Au4, Pt4 and Au2Pt2 tetramers in their rhomboidal and “Y”-like configurations (see Fig. 1 ) were optimized using the PW91 and PBE functionals in combination with the Def2-TZVP basis set at singlet and triplet spin multiplicities. The Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) PW91 includes exchange and correlation functionals developed by Perdew and Wang [47,48]. For its part, the GGA PBE functional has exchange and correlation functionals developed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof [48,49]. Both functionals, the PW91 and the PBE, have been successfully used previously to describe the metals studied here and have been used to study catalysis processes [37,50–53]. The goal of using both functionals, PBE and PW91, in this previous stage is to test their relative validity and relative coherence on the catalysts used here. For its part, Def2-TZVP incorporates scalar relativistic effects for heavy atoms through effective core potentials. For valence electrons it uses valence triple-zeta polarization gaussian functions [54,55], which are necessary to suitably describe the posterior interaction of the clusters with the AB molecule. The Def2-TZVP basis set has been previously used to describe the Au---H interaction [38,56], and other system related to the ones studied here [57]. Additionally, the PW91/Def2-TZVP model chemistry has been tested previously for its validity for the Au4, AB, and AB/Au4 systems with very good results [38]. It is very remarkable that this level of theory reproduces rather well experimental structural parameters available for AB(g) and Au4(g), and also data obtained for these systems at other more sophisticated levels of theory [38]. After comparing the PW91/Def2-TZVP and PBE/Def2-TZVP results for Au4, Pt4 and Au2Pt2 tetramers, all the posterior calculations (PESs scan, energy profiles, bond nature, and reactivity analysis) were made with the PW91/Def2-TZVP level of theory, which was selected for the reasons explained in the section 3.1. This is how the AB structure was optimized at its ground state singlet spin multiplicity and staggered conformation at the PW91/Def2TZVP level of theory. 2.1.2 AB/Au4, AB/Pt4, and AB/Au2Pt2 adducts The following step is to find the appropriate sets of starting structures (candidate structures) for the AB/Au4, AB/Pt4 and AB/Au2Pt2 systems to posteriorly finding their local minima on the PESs by gradient-based usual optimizations. The use of the ASCEC program [58,59] has been very successful for this purpose [37,38,58–63]. This algorithm performs a particular conditioned stochastic search that roughly scans the PESs, moving down from high energy regions to low energy regions. Since the modified Metropolis acceptation criteria contained in ASCEC ensures reasonably probable configurations, the structures are very good candidates to be optimized. Likely, this method is guess-independent and, being stochastic in nature, allows visiting several local minima regions in a same run. This program has been widely explained elsewhere and the reader should refer to the original articles, references [58] and [59]. The quantum energy of each generated configuration within the ASCEC procedure was evaluated at HF/LANL2DZ level of theory. The spin multiplicity of the ASCEC runs was defined according to the multiplicity of the noble metal tetramer considered. In general, for the ASCEC runs, each AB/Au4, AB/Au2Pt2, and AB/Pt4 system were confined in a 6 Å cube, placing both molecules at its center (coinciding mass centers) at the beginning of each run [58,59]. Two ASCEC runs were made for each AB/Au4, AB/Au2Pt2, and AB/Pt4 system by varying the initial pseudo-temperatures, 300 and 500 K, keeping the rest of the parameters fixed (spin multiplicity, cube length, and geometric cooling path of 5%, with the evaluation of 100 pseudo-temperatures) [58,59]. The last step is the optimization of the candidate structures of AB/Au4, AB/Pt4 and AB/Au2Pt2 systems affording by the ASCEC process. It was performed using Gaussian 09 program [46] at singlet and triplet multiplicities with the PW91functional and the Def2-TZVP basis set, without imposition of any symmetry constraints. Calculation of vibrational frequencies for the normal modes of the optimized structures were carried out at the same theory level. This allowed to see which structures are true minima (each with only positive vibrational frequencies) and which ones correspond to transition states (a negative vibrational frequency). 2.2 Energy profiles for the hydrogen release Energy profiles determination for the AB dehydrogenation tendencies on the catalytic systems has been developed in two ways. Both methodologies differ in the form to postulate the implied transition states (TSs). The PESs obtained from the previous stage yield a large number of species consisting of “initially activated AB molecules” and reaction products (in which one or more H atoms have left AB and diffused over the catalyst). Therefore, as a first methodology we formulated paths that connect the found species. For example, having a starting “initially activated AB molecule” and a possible product, by using the Synchronous Transit-Guided Quasi-Newton QST2 methodology [64] at PW91/Def2TZVP level we were able to find the respective TS. After that, by using Berny algorithm [65] at the same level of theory, we proceeded to optimize this TS. The second methodology consists in starting from an identified precursor (“initially activated AB molecules”, or some intermediate in the process of diffusion of a hydrogen atom, etc.) and carrying out rigid and relaxed (with geometry optimization at each point) PES scans, as they are implemented in Gaussian09 [46]. With this process it is possible to detect possible TSs, which are optimized using Berny algorithm [65], and characterized for their normal vibration modes, as described above. Once the TS has been found, the determination of IRCs is carrying out by the Hessian based predictor-corrector integrator algorithm [66]. It is important to emphasize that for all species obtained here, energy minima and TSs, the vibrational analysis as implemented in Gaussian09 [46] was executed. Therefore, to complement the energy profiles for gas phase catalysis (and approximation to homogeneous catalysis), the room temperature thermochemical data are available. 2.3 Bonding interactions and reactivity tendencies Connectivities between atoms can be established from the analysis of electron density (ρ) topology within the framework of the Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) [67]. In QTAIM, the highest electron density paths that connect two electronic density maxima (where the atomic nuclei are located) are called bond paths. All the drawn connections among atoms that appears in the Figures of this work correspond to bond paths, i.e. bonding interactions are based on electronic density topology criteria and not, as usual, on a priori decisions based on empirical radii. The point of minimum electron density along a bond path is called bond critical point (BCP). QTAIM has found that valuable information about the nature of the chemical bonding can be extracted from BCPs properties. The sign of electron density Laplacian at the BCP (∇2ρc) is related to the distribution of electronic density around the internuclear region [67]. If ∇2ρc < 0, then there is an accumulation of electron density and the bond is covalent, while if ∇2ρc > 0, then the electron density is displaced towards one or more nuclei and the interaction is of closed shell nature, as for example, ionic bonds, van Der Waals interactions, hydrogen bonds, etc [67]. There are some cases in which the interaction is of closed shell nature, but the electron density tends to move towards the internuclear region, conferring a certain covalent character to the interaction. Therefore, it is advisable to use the local virial theorem within the framework of QTAIM, and to analyze the relationship between the kinetic and potential energy densities at the BCPs (Gc and Vc, respectively) [68,69]. So, if ǀVcǀ/Gc > 2, the interaction is covalent, if ǀVcǀ/Gc < 1, the interaction is of closed shell nature, and if 1 < ǀVcǀ/Gc < 2, the interaction, although not covalent as such, is “intermediate” with a certain covalent character. In this study it is necessary to determine what interactions are broken and what new ones are formed and with what characteristics (nature of bonding), then we will use the criteria provided by the ǀVcǀ/Gc relationship. All QTAIM calculations were performed with the AIMALL software package [70]. At the last section of this paper, an analysis is offered about the preferred sites of reactivity implied in the interaction of AB and each lowest energy catalyst. In this way, tendencies in reactivity that can be deduced from the natural charges of each atom of the facing molecular species and from the Fukui f−(r) and f+(r) functions [71–73], are stablished. The natural charges are obtained within the Natural Bond Orbitals framework (NBO) [74], as implemented in Gaussian09 [46]. The Fukui f−(r) and f+(r) functions are obtained as: f+(r) = ρN+1(r) − ρN(r) and f−(r) = ρN(r) − ρN−1(r), where ρN(r), ρN−1(r), and ρN+1(r) are the electronic densities of the neutral, monocationic and monoanionic species, respectively, having the geometries of the neutral species. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Potential energy surfaces (PESs) of the AB/Au4, AB/Pt4 and AB/Au2Pt2 systems 3.1.1 Catalysts (Au4, Pt4, Au2Pt2) As was stated and justified in the Introduction section, the rhomboidal and “Y”-like configurations (Fig. 1) are used as starting structures. Table 1 summarizes the ZPE-corrected relative energies for the structures resulting after the optimizations at PW91/Def2-TZVP and PBE/Def2-TZVP levels of theory. Their Cartesian coordinates are in the Supplementary material. As can be observed, from the purely energetic point of view, there are practically no differences between the PBE and PW91 results. This is also true when examining differences in structural parameters. For example, the average deviation percentage in bond lengths for the PBE geometries respect to PW91 ones is of only 0.27% for the same array of structures of Table 1 (see Table S1 of Supplementary material). We conclude that, with respect to the compared pair of functionals, the DFT methodology is coherent for our systems. We choose to work at the PW91/Def2-TZVP level of theory. This is due to the fact that we have previously used PW91 functional [37] and, in particular, this PW91/Def2-TZVP level of theory [38] for the kind of system studied here with very good results. In fact, was the AB/Au4 system the studied one, and here, apart of making a more detailed study and highlighting other not previously examined aspects, we wish to make some comparisons between this previous AB/Au4 study [38] (and the new results) for AB/Au4 and of the other AB/Pt4 and AB/Au2Pt2 systems. Table 1 shows that in the case of Au4 the singlet spin multiplicity “Y”-like and rhomboidal-like are the lowest energy configurations (see the first two structures of Fig. 2 ), and, as has been found by other studies [38,43–45], they are almost isoenergetical. However, as was found by Fielicke et al. [43,45] only the rhomboidal-like is the one present experimentally in a gaseous sample of neutral gold tetramer cluster. The lowest energy structure for the Pt4 case is the distorted (non planar) rhomboidal-like one in triplet spin multiplicity (the third structure of Fig. 2), and for Au2Pt2 case is the “Y”-like one, also in triplet spin state (fourth structure of Fig. 2). 3.1.2 AB/Au4, AB/Pt4, and AB/Au2Pt2 systems The PESs generation process for the AB/catalyst interactions consists in candidate structures production, by means of the ASCEC stochastic procedure, followed by the optimizations of these candidate structures at the PW91/Def2-TZVP theory level (for more details see “Theoretical and computational procedures” section, subsection 2.1). Table 2 summarizes the number of resulting structures at each stage of the process for each type of catalyst starting structure (“Y” or rhomboidal -like) and each global AB/catalyst spin multiplicity. The first thing that can be observed is that the PESs scanning procedure performed here turned out to be quite exhaustive: the number of found candidate structures around low energy regions is high, and, despite coming from very different structures in many cases, several of them give rise to the same optimized final structure. This results in a number of final structures much smaller than that of candidate structures, i.e., with the assurance of having found, among the possible structures, the most probable or representative minima in the respective PES. Fig. 3 shows one representative structure for each generated AB/catalyst PES, i.e., one example for each combination of catalyst start geometry (“Y” –like or rhomboidal–like), with the spin multiplicity (singlet or triplet) and with the type of catalyst (Au4, Pt4 or Au2Pt2), which gives a total of 12 possibilities. The choice of each example is based on its relevance (for example, a global minimum or an AB-catalyst adduct of AB catalytic activation), or on its representativeness as a typical product or remarkable intermediary. These structures will be used in the discussion of below. The totality of resulting structures are showed in the Supplementary material, Figs. S1-S11, together with Cartesian coordinates for structures of Fig. 3. In the m (M4-AB)n (M4 = Au4, Pt4 and Au2Pt2) nomenclature below each structure, m = 1, 3 denote the overall spin multiplicity, and n the nth position in the relative formation energy, being n = 1 the most negative one, n = 2 the second most negative, and so on. Each of these formation energies is the ZPE-corrected difference between the sum of the reactant energies (the AB in singlet spin multiplicity and the tetramer in its starting spin multiplicity) and the energy of the corresponding M4-AB energy minimum in the indicated m spin multiplicity. In this way, a more negative value indicates that the formation of a particular M4-AB structure is a more exothermic process, within a certain starting geometry for M4 and spin multiplicity for the AB-M4 adduct. What can be immediately seen from Table 2 and Figs. S1-S11 is that the largest resulting configurational space is for the AB/Pt4 system with 70 total structures, followed by AB/Au2Pt2 system with 46 structures in total, and finally, by the AB/Au4 system with only 8 total structures. This result indicates that by increasing the amount of Pt in the catalyst, more rich and diverse PESs local minima are achieved with relative ease. That is to say, at first sight, by increasing the amount of Pt the transforming capacities of the catalyst on the AB molecule increase. This is confirmed by the fact that among the lowest energy structures for each geometry and multiplicity only for AB/Pt4 2 cases were obtained (of 4 total cases) in which the NB bond in AB appears broken (see, for example, the r-3(Pt4-AB)1 structure in Fig. 3, and all the structures with the “1″ label (at the right) in the Supplementary material). This speaks for itself of the excessive reactivity of Pt4 tetramers with respect to AB molecule. By contrast, cases of broken B–N bond among Pt2Au2 and Au4 global energy minima were not found. With respect to the AB/Au4 system, the results are coherent with our previous study [38], in which a very small final configurational space was found, being the most probable structure the same 1(Au4-AB)1 geometry found here (see Fig. 3). Another general observation is that there are several cases in which the catalyst geometry changes after the interaction with AB, and that most of these changes are given as interconversions between rhomboidal-like and “Y”-like configurations (see, for example, the cases r-1(Au4-AB)1, r-1(Au2Pt2-AB)1 and Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)4 in Fig. 3). Table 3 summarizes relevant information extracted from all the AB/catalyst energy minima. We have grouped the systems according to the maximum number of hydrogen atoms that resulted detached from AB. In the cases of absence of hydrogen detachment, we have grouped the number of resulting structures with hydrogen-metal interactions according to its bonding nature, or the number of cases without these interactions. This allows to have a preliminary idea (at least from a basic thermal point of view) of reactivity tendency, of the type of products that are easily formed, and of the cases in which an initial adduct of AB activation (AB “adsorption") is formed. The presence or absence of interactions and their nature has been stated using some bonding criteria in the context of QTAIM (see “Theoretical and computational procedures”, subsection 2.3, for explanations of the terms using here). In this way the products with hydrogen detached from AB, have been stated when there are hydrogen-metal formal bonds with ∇2ρc < 0, ǀVcǀ/Gc > 2. The structures with no hydrogen detachment (still with hydrogen binding to B or to N) have been grouped into: (a) structures in which some hydrogen atom interacts strongly with some metal atom, i.e. with 1 < ǀVcǀ/Gc < 2, ∇2ρc > 0. (b) structures in which some hydrogen atom interacts weakly with some metal atom, i.e. with ∇2ρc > 0, ǀVcǀ/Gc < 1, and (c) structures in which there is no hydrogen-metal interaction, i.e. without H–M BCPs. We can summarize the information of this table as: (1) In general, it is easier for the catalysts to detach 1 H atom from AB (see the Y-1(Au4-AB)2, Y-3(Au4-AB)4, Y-1(Pt4-AB)11, and Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)4, structures of Fig. 3 as examples) or to establish a strong H---M interaction (see the Y-1(Au4-AB)2, Y-3(Au4-AB)4, r-3(Pt4-AB)1, r-1(Pt4-AB)2, Y-1(Pt4-AB)11, r-1(Au2Pt2-AB)1, r-3(Au2Pt2-AB)1, Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)4 structures of Fig. 3 as examples), than any other of the possibilities showed in Table 3, being the Pt4 case the most active at this respect, followed by the Au2Pt2 catalyst. In the case of Au4, only for the starting Y-like geometry the scan yielded a 1 H -detached product. “Y”-like seems to be the active configuration for Au4, a result that agrees with our previous study [38]. For the Pt4 and Au2Pt2 cases both initial geometries are active at this respect. (2) Pt4 and Au2Pt2 in both, rhomboidal-like and “Y”-like starting configurations, are active to detach easily more than one hydrogen atom from AB (see the r-1(Pt4-AB)2, r-3(Pt4-AB)1, r-1(Au2Pt2-AB)1, r-3(Au2Pt2-AB)1 structures of Fig. 3 as examples), while Au4 is not. (3) In general, the singlet spin multiplicity shows a greater ease of hydrogen detachment from AB (with 44 cases in total v/s 34 cases for the triplet multiplicity), while the triplet multiplicity shows greater ease of formation of strong interaction adducts (33 cases in total v/s 25 cases for the singlet multiplicity). However, we must be very careful in interpreting this result: as we are not comparing relative energies for transformations at singlet spin state v/s at triplet spin state, we will not know which is the most representative and probable multiplicity for the total system. This aspect can be seen correctly when comparing energy profiles for the AB transformations with the catalysts for both spin multiplicities, which is carried out in the following subsection. Finally, another relevant result is that the most frequent interaction of the AB molecule with the M4 catalysts is by the side of the -BH3 fragment of AB. In fact, the adducts of AB activation (AB “adsorption") are mainly established as a strong H---M interaction, where the H is bonded to boron, and the most common detached hydrogens are those that come from boron (see, for example, structures Y-1(Au4-AB)2, Y-3(Au4-AB)4, Y-1(Pt4-AB)11 and Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)4 in Fig. 3). Likewise, since one of the main experimental problems in the AB dehydrogenation is the poisoning of the catalyst with ammonia, it is important to know if there is simultaneous release of hydrogen from both boron and nitrogen: ammonia results from the breakdown of the B–N bond, therefore, if boron and nitrogen tend to lose the same number of hydrogens, the result is a strong B–N bond, avoiding the toxic NH3 residue. According to the results showed in Figs. S1-S11, this situation of simultaneous detachment happens both in the Pt4 and Au2Pt2 cases (see structures r-1(Pt4-AB)1, r-1(Pt4-AB)2, r-3(Pt4-AB)1, r-3(Pt4-AB)13, Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)3, Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)12, Y-3(Au2Pt2-AB)6, Y-3(Au2Pt2-AB)13, of Figs. S4, S5, S10 and S11 in the Supplementary material), being very remarkable that it also happens for global energy minima: twice for AB/Au2Pt2 (structures r-1(Au2Pt2-AB)1 and Y-1(Au2Pt2-AB)1, Figs. 3, S7 and S9; and once for AB/Pt4: structure Y-3(Pt4-AB)1, Fig. S7). 3.2 Energy profiles for hydrogen release Figs. 4 and 5 show some examples of energy profiles initial steps for the tendencies of catalytic detachment of hydrogen atoms from AB. All energy profiles of Figs. 4 and 5 start from the lowest energy reactants, i.e. from AB and catalysts global minima in their corresponding spin multiplicities, which could be different from overall spin multiplicities of the profiles. The first step consists of the AB-Au4 “adsorption” complex formation (initial AB catalytic activation). Subsequently, a transition state structure for the hydrogen detachment is formed at the top of the energy barrier. These transition stated is indicated by its associated imaginary frequency (values in cm−1). Finally, at the other side of the energy barrier, the first partial product of a hydrogen detachment is shown. In Supported Information, Figs. S12 to S19, there are more examples of more complete energy profiles for the Pt4 and Pt2Au2 cases. The Au4 case is developed in reference [38]. What can immediately be appreciated is that in all cases the implied transition states and intermediaries are of lower energy (Electronic or Gibbs free energy at 298.15 K) than both initial reactants. This means that all processes will occur, and quite quickly. In the Supplementary material many different possibilities are shown for the tendencies towards the AB dehydrogenation by Pt4, (Figs. S12 to S18) which denotes the spontaneity and easiness of the process, especially in this case of the most active catalyst in the transformation of AB. Counting on this background situation, we want to observe some differences and compare the three catalysts, Au4, Pt4 and Au2Pt2, in their relative greater or lesser kinetic tendencies to dehydrogenate the AB molecule. Let’s to start with the monoatomic catalysts, Au4 and Pt4. Fig. 4 shows a contrast between the energy profiles for the detachment of a hydrogen atom for the AB/Au4 and AB/Pt4 systems. The most likely, lowest energy path for AB/Au4 system corresponds to the overall singlet spin multiplicity, such as was stated in our previous study [38]. For the AB/Pt4 case both, the singlet and the triplet spin multiplicity energy profiles are showed. The lowest energy starting geometries for the catalysts are rhomboidal-like in both cases (see section 3.1). As was mentioned above, Fig. 4 shows that in all cases the net process of detachment of a hydrogen atom from AB, assisted by these catalysts, is exothermic and exergonic. It can be appreciated also that the first step of AB-M4 “adsorption” complexes formation has no energy barriers. This last point has also been found in the AB dehydrogenation using other catalysts [75–78], and had been described previously by us for the AB/Au4 system [38]. As previously reported [38], in the AB/Au4 case the hydrogen release barrier is high. However, since the emitted energy in the initial stage of activation of AB (formation of the AB-Au4 “adsorption” complex) is even greater, then this barrier is overcome by the system. For the AB/Pt4 system at both spin multiplicities the situation is even better. The released energies for the initial stage of AB activation are also high for both multiplicities, and the barriers for the hydrogen detachment are very small. Additionally, the first energy minima after the hydrogen detachment have similar or lower energies than the respective AB-Pt4 “adsorption” complexes, while in the AB/Au4 system the respective minimum has higher energy with respect to its AB-Au4 “adsorption” complex. Those factors give faster and more exothermic and exergonic net processes for the AB/Pt4 system, respect to the AB/Au4 one. It is important pointing out that AB-Pt4 system shows other possibilities of one (and multiple) hydrogen atom detachment. In particular, there is one that happens via a rhomboidal-like Pt4 configuration, and overall singlet spin multiplicity (see Fig. S15), that is near in energy to the one showed in Fig. 4 for singlet multiplicity. Considering, additionally, that the interconversion between “Y”-like and rhomboidal-like Pt4 configuration in presence of the AB molecule is of only 6.6 kcal mol−1 (see Fig. S17), we can see that Pt4 shows a richer range of possibilities to remove the hydrogens from AB, than in the case of Au4. By the above considerations it is possible to affirm that from the kinetic point of view both studied monatomic catalysts are able to easily release a hydrogen atom from AB, but Pt4 is much more reactive at this respect than Au4, a result that is in total accordance with what was found in the previous section. Lastly, Fig. 4 shows that singlet and triplet spin multiplicities provide different paths of AB dehydrogenation through Pt4 catalyst, and that the one with singlet spin multiplicity has lower hydrogen release energy barrier and the resulting product has lower energy. However, as both paths are exothermic, exergonic and fast, both of them provide plausible paths of AB dehydrogenation by the Pt4 catalyst. At this point it is convenient to make a clarification about all the interpretations involving the spin states: it is necessary to keep in mind that in systems like the ones we are studying here the spin orbit coupling can be important, therefore, the spin multiplicities under which the paths occur are, in reality, the most contributing spin states to the total electronic state at which the transformation lowest energy paths occur. Therefore, the different paths found for the AB dehydrogenation through Pt4 catalyst are both plausible paths, each with a predominant (singlet or triplet) spin multiplicity contributor to the overall electronic state of the AB/ Pt4 system. On the other hand, Fig. 5 shows a comparison between the Pt4 and Au2Pt2 catalysts for the detachment of two hydrogen atoms from AB for the singlet spin multiplicity, which is the state of lowest energy paths in both cases. For comparison, the case of two-hydrogen detachment for the AB/Pt4 system in triplet spin state is also showed (instead, the AB/Au2Pt2 system in triplet spin state does not show any stable two-hydrogen detachment pathway). Again, in all cases exothermic, exergonic, and fast processes result. For AB/Au2Pt2 and AB/Pt4 at singlet spin states, the emitted energy for the initial step of AB activation is large. Likewise, starting from the respective transition states, there are large energy emissions for the final detachment of the two hydrogens, mediated by relatively small energy barriers to reach the respective transition states. These results imply very fast and strongly exothermic and exergonic total processes. For comparison, Fig. 5 indicates that AB/Pt4 system at triplet overall state, even though has a highly viable two-hydrogen detachment scheme, shows comparatively more difficulties. Profiles of Figs. 4 and 5 constitutes examples of very probable dehydrogenation pathways. Other profiles (see Supplementary material) and the previous subsection induce to a similar overall conclusion: the Pt4 and Au2Pt2 catalysts are, in general terms, more active (thermally and kinetically) in the dehydrogenation of AB than the Au4 catalyst, seeming to be the AB/Au2Pt2 system specially convenient, not only for the reasons given above and in the previous section, but also because, as we shall see, this system has a very convenient separation of charges and combination of local reactivity due to the presence of the two close different atoms, Pt and Au in the same catalyst. 3.3 Reactivity tendencies of AB, Au4, Pt4, and Au2Pt2 From the results of the previous two sections it is evident the presence of certain chemical areas, both in the catalyst and in the AB molecule, with greater susceptibility to interaction that would lead to the observed preferences to form initial activated species and products. The rationalization of these preferences can, in this case, be done by inspecting local Fukui functions [71–73] and natural charges in the reactants. Figs. 6 and 7 show these properties for AB and the lowest energy catalysts, respectively. Fig. 6 clearly shows that the hydrogens bonded to boron are of nucleophilic character. Besides having negative natural charges, their Fukui f−(r) functions are more prominent. On the contrary, Fukui f+(r) functions and natural charges on the hydrogens bonded to nitrogen reveals their electrophilic character. When comparing these data with the ones for each of the lowest energy catalysts (Fig. 7 and also Fig. 1 for the atoms labels) it is possible to observe that: - The nucleophilic hydrogen of AB (bonded to boron) will interact with the 1 and 3 atoms (see Fig. 1) of Au4 in rhomboidal-like configuration (areas of greater f+(r) and positive natural charges, first row of Fig. 7). As was found in this study (for example, in the profile for AB/Au4 in Fig. 4) and as was studied in detail by Mejía et al, [38] the Au4 cluster is highly fluxional and its interaction with AB originates its change to the Y-like configuration. As seen in the second row of Fig. 7, the preferred interaction in this new configuration is with the atoms labeled 1 and 2 (Fig. 1), which contain the highest values for f+(r) and positive natural charges. This description is in accordance with the found initial species: 1(Au4-AB)1 of Fig. 3, profile for AB/Au4 in Fig. 4, and the first ones showed in Figures S1 and S2 of Supported Information. Notice also that in 1(Au4-AB)1 there is a weak interaction between the acidic hydrogen (H–N) of AB with an gold atom of the Au4 cluster, that, according to Fig. 7 (atom 4 of the Y-Au4-S cluster), is nucleophilic. Y-Au4-S structure in Fig. 7 additionally shows that atoms 1 and 2 (Fig. 1) also have high nucleophilic character, which makes it possible to explain that the structure that follows in energy for Au4-AB (structure 1(Au4-AB)2 of Fig. 3) is one in which hydrogen bound to nitrogen in AB is interacting with one of atoms 1 or 2 of Au4. - For the Pt4 cluster, in the third row of Fig. 7, it can be appreciated that all atoms are almost indistinctly nucleophilic and electrophilic (similar f−(r) and f+(r) indices and natural charges for all atoms). This would explain, in part, the great reactivity and the large number of possibilities and ways of reaction for this catalyst. - Au2Pt2 (fourth row of Fig. 7) presents charge polarization, with the positive sign located at Platinum atom labelled with 1 (highest f+(r), but also high value of f−(r)), and the negative one at gold atom 4 (high value of f−(r)). The other two natural charges tend to be neutral, but with a slight positive value for Pt and negative for Au. Therefore, hydrogens of boron tend to interact with platinum atoms and hydrogens of nitrogen tend to interact with gold atoms, such as observed in the PESs results for Au2Pt2 (see Supplementary material) and in the energy profile of Fig. 5. These results indicate that having nearby platinum and gold atoms in a catalytic cluster ensures that both the boron and nitrogen hydrogens simultaneously have contiguous sites of interaction in the catalyst. This possibility the simultaneous release of both types hydrogen (such as was found for this system), and the consequent solution to the problem of poisoning the catalyst by ammonia, and a certain order in the process of hydrogen evolution. 4 Conclusions and finals remarks This theoretical comparative study of catalytic dehydrogenation tendencies allows to conclude that: 1) All the metal tetramers studied here, Au4, Pt2Au2, Pt4, tends to dehydrogenate the ammonia borane molecule, being the processes exothermic, exergonic and fast. 2) The activity in the catalytic transformation of AB increases with the Pt content in the order Au4, Pt2Au2, Pt4. The Pt4 system is so reactive that tends to break the N-B very easily (giving very probable, low energy products with B and N separated), which makes Pt4 less useful for AB deshydrogenation than the others tetramers, due to catalyst poisoning by ammonia releasing. 3) Pt2Au2 is the best system for AB dehydrogenation: it is capable of easily detaching several hydrogen atoms, with high probability of taking them out simultaneously, both from B and N, which helps in avoiding the breakage of B–N bond of AB (poisoning of the catalyst). This property is due to the presence of a Pt atom (which have affinity with hydrogen of boron), close to an Au one (with affinity to nitrogen hydrogen). As indicated in the introduction of this paper, there are experimental evidence of better catalytic capacity of the Pt clusters with respect to those of Au for the dehydrogenation of AB, but in different conditions to those of our study [26,27], so, at least in broad terms, this point is in accordance with our results. Likewise, others experimental studies showed improvements of catalytic activity and selectivity in the transformation of molecules such as alcohols or oxygen after replacement of pure gold or pure platinum clusters catalysts by combined gold-platinum clusters catalysts [79,80], being, in one of these studies [79], the ratio 1:1 (platinum:gold) the optimal one. Similarly, there are theoretical studies reporting improvements in the capacities of transformation of O2, CO, NO, and CH3OH by doping small gold clusters catalysts with platinum [50,81]. Even though these studies are for the transformation of other molecules different from AB, and they were carried out under conditions that may be very different from ours, their results are in line with what was reported by us here. With respect to our specific case, there is still no experimental evidence for the reactivity differences among Au4(g), Pt4(g) and Pt2Au2(g), and even less about their catalytic capacities to transform AB. As the structures and chemical properties of small metal clusters are sensitive to their charge state and chemical medium, the exact experimental corroboration of our results must be carried out in gas-phase and in neutral charge state. For this reason experimental techniques such as mass spectroscopy in the usual modality [82], among others, are of limited applicability. However, special techniques such as far-IR multiple photon dissociation in a molecular beam [43,45,83,84] allows registering the IR spectra of both, the molecule being transformed catalytically [84] and the catalysts itself (the metal cluster, i.e. with far IR spectral region [43,45,83],). As a complement, it is also possible carrying out mass spectra of the species resulting from the interaction of AB and each catalyst, by means of their ionization with the suitable photon of high energy, just after they are formed [84]. By means of these methodologies it would be possible studying (in some degree) sequentially the interaction of each gaseous cluster with AB, and thus, comparing the reactivity and possible selectivity according to the formed products. coredata.dc:description: Small metallic clusters -mediated gas phase catalysis studies give lights to understand simple and complex catalytic processes, and help in the discovery and explanation of non-traditional “molecular-scale” catalytic systems. In this framework and in the context of clean energy sources based on hydrogen, a comparative study about ammonia borane (AB = NH3BH3) dehydrogenation tendencies, using Pt4, Au4, and Pt2Au2 clusters as catalysts, is made. Molecular details on thermal, kinetic (mechanistic) and reactivity factors are revealed. Our results indicate that all the metal tetramers studied here tends to dehydrogenate the ammonia borane molecule, being the processes exothermic, exergonic and fast. Among the studied catalysts, Pt2Au2 shows the best results, because is capable of easily detach several hydrogen atoms, with high probability of taking them out simultaneously, both from B and N, which helps in avoiding the breakage of B–N bond of AB, what is known to produce the poisoning of the catalyst by ammonia generation.
coredata.dc:title: Ammonia borane dehydrogenation tendencies using Pt4, Au4, and Pt2Au2 clusters as catalysts
